note.p: “Rich with the spoils of many a Hartzwald mine” (Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXXV)—“The dome of the Cathedral of St. Hubert is covered with copper; and there are many altars and shrines in the interior constructed of different sorts of marble, brought from quarries in the vicinity. St. Hubert, to whom the Cathedral is dedicated, was by birth a Scotchman”. [Ruskinʼs note.]

“statues, richly wrought, / And noble paintings, from Ausonia brought,— / Planned by those master minds whose memory stands / The grace, the glory, of their native lands” (MS VIII; Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXXV)—Echoes The Restoration of the Works of Art to Italy: A Poem (1816) by Felicia Hemans, which commemorates the return of artworks that had been removed from Italy to the Louvre in Paris by Napoleon's agents in 1797 and afterward. On terms of treaties concluded in the wake of Napoleon's defeat, artworks began to be restored to their prewar origins in 1815-16. In the passage near the start of Hemans's poem on which Ruskin appears to draw most directly, the poet has been contrasting the "immortal strains" of Italy as the "Land of departed fame" with "the strain" of the modern victors "whose warrior-might . . . prevail'd":

lg.l: And well, Ausonia! may that field of fame [i.e., Waterloo]
From thee one song of echoing triumph claim.
Land of the lyre! ʼtwas there thʼ avenging sword,
Won the bright treasures to thy fanes restored;
Yes! fair creations, to perfection wrought,
Forms of sublimity! by Genius traced,
In tints that vindicate adoring taste;
Whose bright originals, to earth unknown,
Live in the spheres encircling gloryʼs throne;
Models of art, to deathless fame consignʼd,
Stampʼd with the high‐born majesty of mind;
Yes, matchless works! your presence shall restore
One beam of splendor to your native shore,
And her sad scenes of lost renown illume,
As the bright Sunset gilds some Heroʼs tomb.

note.p: Drawing on Hemans's poem, Ruskin's lines retain the sinister suggestion that the statues and paintings were not just "brought" to Salzburg from Ausonia (i.e., Italy), but purloined. For another allusion to Napoleon's confiscation of artwork, see Account of a Tour on the Continent: Cologne [essay].

The term Ausonia appears only in the second, lengthier edition of Hemans's poem, published by John Murray, indicating that this was the edition owned or borrowed by the Ruskins. In the remainder of the poem, Hemans describes, in the order mentioned by Ruskin, "statues, richly wrought", and then "noble paintings". By concentrating on classical statues, she touches on repatriation to various Italian cities--the Venus de' Medici restored to Florence; one of the bronze horses from atop San Marco Cathedral returned to Venice; the Apollo Belvedere, the Belvedere Torso, and the Laocoön reinstated in the Vatican (although Hemans was mistaken that the Torso had been removed). Toward the end of the poem, Hemans turns to the restoration of Italian Renaissance paintings, culminating in the return of Raphael's Transfiguration to the Vatican (see Hemans, Selected Poems, ed. Wolfson, 31-33 nn. 15, 21, 29, 31, 34, 43). Hemans's ekphrastic poem would have provided Ruskin with an early introduction to these famous works.

The term Ausonian, a Greek term poetically applied to Italy, appears also in "Spoleto", a poem by Ruskin's editor, Thomas Pringle, which like "Saltzburg" is an ekphrastic treatment of a drawing by William Purser.
